resources.string: This application allows researchers to find appropriate power and sample size for one-way ANOVA. \n\nThe TITLE was developed at the Colorado School of Public Health, Department of Biostatistics and Informatics at the University of Colorado of Denver.

The software was written by Sarah Kriedler, Uttara Sakhadeo, Aarti Munjal ..... with support from NCI K07CA88811, a grant from the National Cancer Institute of Science to the Colorado School of Public Health, Dr. Deborah Glueck, Principal Investigator. 

The power calculations are based on the work of Dr. Keith E. Muller at the University of Florida. Appropriate citations for the supporting publications are available on the related publications page. 

For inquiries about the current versionof the application or to report a bug please email ......
List of inputs. Please click on each tab for more details.

To begin your calculation please indicate whether you would like to solve for power or total sample size. 

Power: If you know the number of participants you can recruit. 

Sample Size: If you would like to ensure a well-powered study.

string.name: description_tutorial_alpha
string.p: Type I error indicates the probability of incorrectly identifying a significant difference when there is none (i.e. rejecting a tru null hypothesis). Type I error values range from 0 to 1. The most commonly used values are 0.01, 0.05 and 0.1

string.name: description_tutorial_groups
string.p: To begin your calculation please indicate the total number of groups for the design.

string.name: description_tutorial_relative_size
string.p:
Specify whether the study subgroups are of equal or unequal size. 

For equal sizes, select a "1" in the drop down list next to each study dubgroup. This is the default study design. 

For unequal group sizes, specify the ratio of the group sizes.

string.name: description_tutorial_smallest_group
string.p: Specify the smallest number of participants in the smallest group

string.name: description_tutorial_mean_variance
string.p:
In power analysis it is necessary to provide mean values for the outcomes. The means are often obtained from published results or pilot data. 

Means: Enter the mean values you expect to observe for each outcome within each study subgroup. 

Within Each Group Variance: Enter standard deviation for the study outcomes. The standard deviation value shout reflect the variability within a study subgroup.

resources.string: Enter the number of groups to be analyzed.
Enter Type I Error for the analysis.
Specify the smallest number of participants in the smallest group.

Choose sample size if you have fewer restrictions on recruitment and would like to ensure a well-powered study. 

Chose power if you have a rough idea of number of research participants you will be able to recruite.
Please fill in the details for mean and variance.
This will lose the information. Do you want to proceed?
